clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Dietary Interventions on the Brain in Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
clinical_study.official_title: Enhancing Memory Functions in Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment by Dietary Interventions and in Combination With Exercise and Cognitive Training - Proof of Concept and Mechanisms

collaborator.agency: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research

brief_summary.textblock: The study will investigate whether dietary modification could provide positive effects on brain functions in elderly people with mild cognitive impairment.

detailed_description.textblock:
The age-related degradation of cognitive functions even to the point of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer`s disease are a growing public-health concern with devastating effects.
Referring to animal data, empirical studies, and pilot human trials, dietary modification (caloric restriction, omega-3 fatty acids and resveratrol) should improve cognitive functions such as learning and memory. To test this hypothesis, the researchers study general brain functions in elderly subjects (50-80 years old) with mild cognitive impairment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- subjects with mild cognitive impairment
- 50-80 years old
- moderate to heavy weight (BMI 25-35)
Exclusion Criteria:
- dementia
- diabetes
- severe disease
- younger than 50 years
- BMI < 25
